reviewText: The 1999 TNT original film 'Purgatory' is a unique and throughly enjoyable watch. Much like the classic 'Twilight Zone television series a specific time period and a seemingly ordinary place serve as the setting for an extremely unorthox tale. The time period is the American Old West, the place a small, off-the-beaten-path town known as Refuge. It is here that the world we know intersects with another and things are seldom what they appear to be. When a gang of outlaws ride into town they think they've come upon a place ripe for the picking and decide to take over and do as they please. Again, in the town of Refuge things are not exactly what they seem to be.If you're the kind of person who enjoys a good western, a quirky, out of the ordinary storyline and can appreciate a little morality tale as long as it's not preachy than this is the film for you.
summary: "Bullets Tend To Do That" ~ Life On The Edge Of Eternity

reviewText: This movie is about a small western town where people try to be as good a Christian as possible.  It is visited (by accent) by some gangsters who are fleeing from justice.As the story develops, one finds out that the people in the town are actually in Purgatory, where they are given one last chance to either go to heaven or hell.Not everybody makes it to heaven.  the gangsters start creating trouble in the town, so several of them Purgatorians arm themselves to protect the honor of the young woman who is being abused.  They full well knew that putting on guns could cause them to lose their opportunity for heaven, but they put themselves on the line to protect the young woman.  After ridding the town of the gangsters, the story has an interesting twist as they are being summoned to hell.While this story is hardly theologically stimulating, it is a nice story and fun to watch.

reviewText: Does mighteous make righteous?  That's the question in this odd, mystically allegorical made-for-TV western... A gnarly crew of outlaws wind up in a mysteriously peaceful border town, where borderline bad guys are given a chance at redemption by the powers that be.  It gets a little syrupy in the second half, but I was into it.  Always nice to see Sam Shepard flaunt his grizzle.
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: I thought this was a great western... I wished I hadn't passed it up at the video store months ago... but after reading the reviews on here, I just bought it, and I'm not dissapointed.It's fantastic, great film quality, scenes, and special effects (nothing outrageous or unbelievable)great gun-play, knife fighting, and a true old-west feel... nothing sci-fi, like some of the reviews I've read.  Some people think religeous overtones is sci-fi ???  not at all...  it's just that religeous / spiritual overtones mixed with the appropriate special effects, and you get a very believable story that makes you think about your own life, and the meaning of life in general... you can't help but to think about life after death, because the movie takes places in the after-life of some of the worlds greatest gunslingers like Billy The Kid, Doc Holiday, Jesse James, Wild Bill Hickok, and more... sounds too fictional, huh?  Well, the script and the storyline itself, pulls it off without being too cliche or too Hollywood.As a Western fan, I love it, as a Believer I appreciate it, and as a man wanting to sit and watch a good movie with family, friends, or even kids, I enjoy it!
summary: old-style western with a new theme...  makes you think about life
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: Alright, first let me say I enjoyed this for what it was - a Tv movie.  I liked the concept and the message enjoyed the overall execution, but a couple things really bothered me...1. `Doc' John Holliday was a dentist, not a medical doctor.2. Why did the gunfight at the end take place, when it was already depicted that the Higher Power would protect the town's citizens so long as they didn't resort to violence (remember when Sam Sheppard stands in front of the church door to stop the baddies from tossing their bowie knives?)?  And how could the citizens be harmed by the bad guys anyway, considering their true nature?3.  So Purgatory is located just south of Sweetwater, Texas?  How could Ric Roberts and his gang ride into this place, and why didn't the posse follow them in?  Its hard to believe such a huge gang could give the lawmen the slip and not leave a clear trail for them to follow.4. Why would such a formidable (and large) gang of bank robbers put all the money they'd just swiped on one horse?Overall, as I said, I enjoyed this.  The actors all do a good job -particularly Eric Roberts, who was the biggest misgiving I had going into this.  He came off completely believable and seductively bad (which was good).  Donnie Wahlberg does a lot with the little screen time he's given, as does Randy Quaid and the fella who plays `JJ' (the storekeeper).  Sam Sheppard doesn't look a whit like who he's supposed to be portraying, but it didn't bother me.I like the notion that `The marginally good' are given a chance to separated from `the totally wicked,' and I like the supernatural theme of redemption.  I thought the passage of the bad guys through the ghostly gates was very Twilight Zonish, and eerie, but I wish they hadn't shown us what was beyond all that smoke.  It kind've ruined the effect.Overall, a good effort, worth renting, but I don't know about putting it up as one of the greatest westerns of all time.If you wanna see a really stellar made-for-cable western, check out John Cusack, LQ Jones, and John Goodman in `The Jack Bull.'

reviewText: I don't care about westerns and, when I found this on videotape and it was just a dollar or so, I wanted to try it out based on the mystical nature it described.Outlaws, fleeing the law with money they stole from a robbery, come upon the the town of Refuge. That turns out to be a haven on the 'other side' where souls are waiting. Classic legends of the Old West are found there (like Billy the Kid and Doc Holliday). They want to redeem themselves for their actions while they were alive, so there's no cursing....fighting...etc. However, the town still has a saloon and one can get drunk. As well, there are guns and ammo (as we learn later) and it seems stupid that things that could tempt them to resort to their old ways, like in real-life, would be present.The outlaws realize how nobody -- not even the sheriff -- carries a weapon and there's no jail. So, the town's easy for the pickin'. Eventually, when the entire town is in danger of destruction and bloodshed, the former gunslingers decide to defend themselves and the rest of the folks...knowing that it's going to mean they 'fail' and will be lost for eternity.If it's a place for souls to be until they are ready for heaven (or hell if they 'fail'), there's no way that regular-folks should be there. The gang of desperados couldn't appear. That's something that will always be wrong with the story. I figured at the beginning that the gang was all dead when they came upon the town of Refuge and didn't realize it. It was what I thought because of the name of the movie + the town looked a bit eerie and the leader of the gang spoke of how they made a wrong turn or the wind made them get sidetracked (whatever).So....the spirits of the famous gunslingers of the Old West take charge to defend their town from the living desperados. By doing so, an knowing what it means, they 'failed' and are to be taken to hell by an Indian spirit/man. However, before this, an old man in stagecoach comes at the last moment and tells them something like "The Creator may be strict, but He ain't blind." Thus, the four gunslingers get a reprieve, get into the stagecoach, and are taken down the road to heaven. The end. What did they all really do that was good? In their final actions, they killed humans that were somehow in the spirit realm and that's what they needed to do to 'earn' heaven? There's nothing we can do to earn heaven. The Creator said so; many of us are blind or deaf to understanding that. I guess we're supposed to think that because the gunslingers were protecting others and using their weapons to selflessly help instead of harm, unlike when they were alive, was enough.Oh...and how about Sonny? He's one member of the gang who's pretty innocent and new to the group. He shoots & kills one of the men on horseback who shot him at the same time. Instantly, he spoke of how he's not in any pain and the sheriff welcomes him to Refuge. Sonny just died. Now later, at the stagecoach, he's invited to come aboard as well. Apparently, this was because he was the first one standing up to the desperados and protected the woman (spirit) he said he loved (though he didn't even know her) from gunfire. It's not clear to me, but I think that's the reason. He told the woman earlier that he killed one man who asked him to do it (we witness this happening earlier in the movie) and the second man he killed was the one who would have killed (???) the woman/spirit. So, both of Sonny's executions weren't acts done in revenge. He ends up choosing to remain in the town with the woman and becoming the new sheriff, knowing that -- according to the stagecoach driver -- he can leave when he wants.VARIOUS OTHER THOUGHTS:- When chiding the man about saying "da*n", I figure the sheriff shouldn't have repeated it. "You said 'da*n' ... twice!" To me, it would have been keeping in the character of the sheriff at the time if he said "You said the d-word ... twice!" This sheriff's time was almost up in Refuge.- The residents of Refuge, since they aren't living-beings, couldn't be harmed by the humans. Before the final shootout, one mentions how if they fight, they lose (because it would mean they will be banished)...if they do nothing they lose (die? again?). If everyone there was a spirit, however, there'd be no flick. A western with all the bullets passing right through everyone?- Why would the residents all go by different names? Who would care? They know who they are. There's to be no swearing in the town. The fact that they lie about who they are, well, that should be on the 'naughty list' too.- When Sonny shoots and kills the man on the horse, why does the body just lie there? The dude's spirit should then be there -- just like with Sonny. He dies right away from that same man's shots and he doesn't fall, saying that he's not in any pain. Also, what about when the sheriff kills the leader "Black Jack"? His spirit should then have appeared, too.Yes, this is meant to be a western and a supernatural-type of film, obviously not meant to be taken seriously, but I want to mention that I believe the concept of purgatory is unscriptural. It implies that the death and resurrection of Jesus was not enough. To say such a thing and believe that we'll still need to be in a place of purification before heaven is insulting to why the Father sent Jesus here. Jesus' sinless life, sacrificial death for us, and resurrection is what was required to make is possible for any man to get right with God. "It is finished."This is a silly flick and yet I found it okay to pass the time with. I liked most of the acting, especially the sheriff's; it moves rather-briskly; and I wasn't bored. A two-star rating seems generous.
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: B Western but better than some
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: A Western town without a jail and a saloon without customers.  How?  It's Purgatory.  Wild Bill Hickok (Sam Shepard), Doc Holliday (Randy Quaid) and Jesse James (JD Souther of music fame) all wait for the moment they're taken out of Refuge to finally make it to the "Great Prairie in the Sky".A band of banditos with one not-so-bad bandito is nearby.  Sonny (Brad Rowe), the not-so-bad decides it's time to get out of the gang and mosey's his way over to the townsfolk.  Readily accepted to their bosom, Sonny helps put a stop to BlackJack's decision to take over the town.The movie's well worth viewing once and possible even twice.
summary: Purgatory is Refuge and Refuge Isn't to be Messed With
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: Purgatory is a great Western by itself, however it is the inner story about redemption, salvation, and temptation which really makes it good.  It suggests that even the most wicked among us deserve a chance to redeem themselves.  Bad people of the old West like Billy the Kid, Wild Bill Hickock, and Jesse James have a chance to live exemplary lives to prove they deserve to be saved.  In the end, on the eve of Wild Bill Hickock's redemption day, he has to choose between doing what serves him best, or what is best for the people of the town.  He volunteers his own soul to save theirs.  Convinced he is going to be thrown into the fiery pit at the end of the movie, the "stagecoach" driver comes by, opens the door, and says, "The Almighty my be tough but he ain't blind.  Climb aboard."  And the bad men are saved.
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: There has been some complaining about Quaid in this one. AS near as I can tell, his portrayal of Doc Holiday fits what the real outlaw was like - surly, laconic,  and short tempered.I have no complaints at all, except maybe it doesn't explain enough soon enough, however, patience has never been my strong suit.The best part about this movie is that you can watch it with literally anyone (wife, girlfriend, friend, preacher, grandmother, etc.). It gets your attention and keeps it.Some religionists may be put off by the idea that one's afterlife may be decided after death rather than before it. That's another thing I like about it.

reviewText: I'm a fan of ghost stories and had been expecting (and hoping) for something eerier.  Once the outlaw gang got to Refuge, however, my expectations and hopes were no longer important.  This is a lovely film, surprisingly (and refreshingly) free of the everything-but-the-kitchen-sink-and-we-may-have-that-too motifs of sex, blood, more sex, more blood, lots of the "F" word, more sex, lots more blood, and (just for something different) bloody sex with lots of the "F" word.  I was stunned that the writers and producers managed to churn out a flick that was entertaining, comfortably familiar  and just a little unpredictable. You could share this movie with your kids, your Mom and Dad  and your aunt the Nun and not squirm with embarrassment. (Intelligent grown-up movies that you can watch with your kids!  What a clever concept!) I was reaching for kleenex during the last twenty minutes.  How nice to see that it is still considered courageous when someone chooses to make a tough, personally detrimental sacrifice in order to preserve the greater good. People here have been calling this a "sci-fi" film, but I think the classification is more "religious fantasy with western overtones."  Whatever the case, if you like westerns, if you like the pitting of good against evil, if you are sick of the blood, gore, swearing and sex that pass for action entertainment these days...and if you believe in something greater than yourself, then by all means, you should be watching "Purgatory."
summary: A Pleasant Surprise and Not What I Expected

reviewText: I caught this movie on TV last night after a hiatus of several years.  It was a made-for-TV film run on TNT, and should be shown a lot more often.  It could have stood on its own as a feature in any theater as a great piece of movie making.A gang of outlaws headed by the notorious Blackjack Britton lams out of town after a bank robbery and gets lost in a dust storm with the posse on their trail.  They take a wrong turn, evading the posse, and come upon a spooky little place with a gated entrance guarded by an ancient Indian, who turns out to be keeping more than one gate.  Was it luck or fate that brought them here?  The townspeople all seem peculiarly docile.  The sheriff wears a badge but not a gun.  And Sonny, the youngest of the outlaw band and addicted to dime western novels, not an outlaw himself but who went along for the ride with his uncle, one of the gang members, realizes that the sheriff is a dead ringer for Wild Bill Hickock and the sheriff's friends look exactly like Doc Holliday, Billy the Kid, Jesse James and Lefty Slade, all dead for years.  In fact, that's just who they turn out to be, and the town, called Refuge, is nowhere on earth, but is actually Purgatory, a mid-world created for people who are neither good enough to be admitted to Heaven nor bad enough to be condemned to Hell.  Purgatory is their last chance to set themselves right before their final sentencing.  But as the sheriff tells Sonny, Refuge is a place of hard rules: no cussing, no fighting, no rioting, no stealing, no violent outbursts no matter what the provocation -- and one of the sheriff's friends finds out tragically just what the penalty for breaking those rules is.Blackjack Britton and his gang see Refuge as a place to cut loose and raise all kinds of mayhem, and for a while the sheriff tries to deal with the situation through polite admonitions.  But the sheriff and his friends realize that some evil is too entrenched to be dealt with by patience and docility, and sometimes one must resort to extreme measures, if not for his own benefit, then for the good of the people he must protect.  And who knows, maybe at times giving evil people a taste of their own medicine is justified.  As a wily old stagecoach driver observes, "The Creator may be tough, but He ain't blind."Uli Edel's direction and Gordon T. Dawson's script lift the movie beyond what might have been a banal western into the truly sublime, helped by a superb cast that includes Sam Shepard as Wild Bill Hickock, Eric Roberts in what may be his finest performance as Blackjack Britton, Randy Quaid as Doc Holliday, Donnie Wahlberg as Billy the Kid, J.D. Souther as Jesse James, Brad Rowe as Sonny, and Peter Stormare as Blackjack's henchman and Sonny's evil uncle Cavin Guthrie.  It's a perfect little gem of a western, of the kind they don't make any more, with the added treat of a tender love story running through it all.Judy Lind
summary: Great little western from straight out of the Twilight Zone
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: I bought this DVD - (1) because I wanted to see how purgatory would be folded into the western genre of film making; (2) because I recognized the names Eric Roberts, Sam Shepard, Randy Quaid, and Amelia Heinle; (3) because it is "not rated" which leaves room for violence, terror, and nudity without apology; and (4) most westerns have the people killed who deserve it.What I got by owning and viewing this DVD - (1) hell is a ditch where somebody is burning weeds, heaven is a stagecoach, and the gate keeper is a Native American Indian; (2) to move from purgatory to heaven you can't smoke, drink, cuss, or chew, or go with girls that do - and you can't carry a gun because you can't kill anybody (well okay . . . unless they REALLY, REALLY deserve it); (3) "not rated" means it was on TV so it's about as milquetoast as you're ever going to find in any western of any vintage all the way back past Tom Mix (violence, terror, or nudity? don't make me laugh); and (4) by the time the movie finally gets around to the gunfight, I didn't care if everybody died, as long as the movie was over.The movie sets up the pretense of Blackjack Britton (Eric Roberts) being a vile, nasty and deserving of death outlaw early, which made me want Jack Palance to show up, pull out a Crocodile Dundee blade and slit the bad guy neck to nuts.  Spoiler alert - Jack Palance does not appear in this film.  Instead, "Purgatory" delivers Wild Bill Hickock, Doc Holliday, and Billy the Kid; not even carrying a gun, let alone willing to do anything whatsoever toward putting the town of Refuge back to safety and justice by dealing with Blackjack Britton - one way or another.  Nothing . . . . until finally there is a short gunfight, at the end of the movie.  Some are led by the Native American Indian to the ditch of burning weeds, some go to the stagecoach.  Meh.
summary: sadly short of what could have been so, so much more . . .
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: I have been an enthusiastic fan of westerns most of my life.  This is a made for TV movie but do not let that discourage you from seeing this unusual and unique western DVD.  This film begins with a bank robbery by a vicious group of very bad characters.  They end up in a shoot-out and ride out of town chased by the law.  They end up losing the money but most of the gang gets away from the law men.  As they are riding in any unknown area  they enter a fog and end up in a small peaceful western town called "Refuge."  Strangely, the gang is greeted by the sheriff, who is unarmed and extends a welcome to the group.  This is where the story becomes interesting and mysterious.I never give away too much when reviewing a book or movie, which will spoil it for those who want to see this movie.  I will say that most of the top gunfighters of the old west (Wild Bill Hickok, Doc Holiday, Jessie James and Billy the kid) are in this movie.  Like all good movies this one has all the ingredients of a unique and imaginative action packed western.  If you are into western movies that have an interesting twist and great characters, you should check out this movie.  I love this movie.Rating:  5 Stars.  Joseph J. Truncale  (Author: The Samurai Soul: An old warrior's poetic tribute)
summary: An interesting twist combining an action packed western with a moral theme.  If you like westerns you should check this one out
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: A bit more coherent than Dwight Yoakam's personal offering perhaps, but I am not sure 'logical' is a good thing when the subject is a Western set in the afterlife.  In any event, having loved "SOHWOH", I spent a good bit of my time while watching "Purgatory" trying to decide 'who copied who'.  "Purgatory" was released first (1999/2000), but my understanding was that Dwight had "SOHWOH" in his pocket for a good while before getting it made....so the question that was distracting me was not something I am going to be able to answer....but, I did reaize I was on the 'right track' when late in "Purgatory" I heard the gutteral utterings of 'Come On....', talk about paying homage.Anyway, Purgtory had a great cast, but they all seriously underplayed their roles a bit.  I mean afterall, these were supposed to THE personalities of the old west; but they were certainly an understated group of BAD GUYS.  Given the subject matter, the film was certainly easy to understand (not a trademark of "SOHWOH" I might add), but that sort of made "Purgatory" come off as a bit of an 'immature film'.  I mean shouldn't something this fanciful be a bit theatrical?  The actors seemed to be portraying zombies rather than individuals still striving to get their journey 'to the light' completeted in a positive manner.  In order words, maybe the reason the film was so easily understandable was that the viewer had no trouble knowing the characters were dead....because they acted that part perfectly.Watching "Purgatory" was an okay way to spend a Friday night at home.  Not too much stress on the gray matter, nothing exciting enough to get the keep you from relaxing after a week of hard work, and just enough story to keep you interested, even if it is only to consider the question of which came first "Purgatory" or "SOHWOH".My conclusion:  If you disliked Dwight's tale, you will probably like "Purgatory" - and vice versa.
summary: Reminded me of 'South of Heaven West of Hell
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: This is movie is creative and unusual in a very good way. It is not easy to come up with an original take on your "stock" western movie, but Purgatory does just that. An otherwordly, supernatural flair makes this somewhat religiously oriented film unlike any western I have seen before. Well-acted and worth watching. A really enjoyable flick.
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: I am not a huge fan of Western movies but I decided to watch Purgatory because there was nothing else on TV and it was better than doing the housework that was for sure!  Boy am I glad I gave the housework a miss! What an excellent film!  It wasn't just a western but it was a love story, a mystery, a thriller, a bit of horror and lots of good quality acting. The storyline was fairly simple. A group of rowdy cowboys come across a small town called Refuge and they think that their luck is in.  It's run by a Sheriff who doesn't tote a gun, and the locals are wary of trouble to the point of paranoia.  Enter Sonny portrayed by the delicious young Brad Rowe as an idealistic young cowboy who is the first to realise that the town of Refuge isn't quite what it seems.  There are familiar faces in the town, faces that have been dead for many years and they're all pretending to be people that they aren't.  Sonny goes looking for the truth and in doing so falls in love with Rose a Refuge local played by newcomer Amelia Heinle.  In order to save Rose from the outlaws he has been travelling with Sonny must take on a band of vicious men, and make Wild Bill Hickok, Sam Shepherd at his best, pick up his guns once more even though it means a fate worse than death for him.  This is a great film, with a great storyline that is made even better by a strong cast of actors.  Look out for Donnie Wahlberg who plays Deputy Glen/Billy The Kid, he's an absolute cutie-pie!  It's not too graphic in the horror department so those who are squeamish can watch it without too much hiding behind pillows, and it has enough suspense for those who want a film with a little bit of a bite here and there.  All in all a really good film, and a western at that!!
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: While the above information states the year 1999 for a release date, I believe that date is only for the release to video. I swear I saw this movie a year or two before then. Also, this movie is a TNT original, and I don't think it was ever in the theaters. But let me clarify, it could have done very well at theaters. This movie does not come across as 'made for television'. In fact, it is better than 95% of the movies currently on the big screen. I should state that, like many others here, I am not a big fan of westerns, and movies with religious undercurrents generally turn me right off. Thus, when my girlfriend wanted to watch this when it was first shown on TNT one night, I was not too excited by the idea. About 15 minutes into the film, my mind was totally changed and I was absolutely riveted to the screen. I was stunned by the subtle-but-immediate effect this movie was having on me. If my house would have started on fire, I don't think I'd have noticed.This movie is pretty much impossible to categorize. It looks and feels like a western, but it's not. It also feels a bit like sci-fi, but it's not. Its message is deep and profound, but easy to understand instinctively. I've seen hundreds of movies, but I've never seen casting done this well before. All characters come across beautifully. This is not a huge-budget movie, Hollywood style, but you'll never notice the difference. I'm sure a large amount of money was spent, but this movie makes it due to stellar storytelling, great acting and wonderful direction, not big special effects. A powerful movie that can be enjoyed by the whole family. No matter how old you are when you first see it, the story is likely to haunt you for years to come. A highly, highly recommended film.
Title: Purgatory VHS

Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: PURGATORY in a western setting! It is a mind boggling concept.And what a great way to think of that might have happened to our "bad boys".Take a kid [Brad Rowe] who is not wholly "bad", still with a touch of innocence to slowly stumble onto what might be happening in the town of Refuge.Eric Roberts made a great "Blackjack", a devil driven badass who was arrogant enough to think he can rule and destroy Refuge.What a shock to find out was a "Hell" waiting for him.  Loved that scene.It didn't take long to realize that Randy Quaid was "Doc Holliday" but I couldn't place the others until they were pointed out to me.Sam Shepard as "Wild Bill Hickock" wanting only peace to finish his stay in Refuge was a wonderful, powerful character.  Especially when he faced down the knife throwers.  What retribution!I loved the use of an Indian guarding the gates to Refuge and his removal of the bodies.  He was a great character.The mix of spiritualism with the western setting and including falling in love, the driving force of the universe, is what helped to make this a great movie.  Not the run of the mill Hollywood tripe!We get the feeling that God does love his creatures and is willing to forgive if we put forth the effort to ask for forgiveness.  And that He does reward man's acts of heroism put forth for those that can't defend themselves.This DVD is well worth the money and can be enjoyed by all.DEFINITELY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED -- a keeper of the highest degree!Actually an 8 + rating.
summary: WHAT A GREAT WAY TO REPRESENT PURGATORY!
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: PURGATORY is an old fashioned western----right out of the Twilight Zone.  With its imaginative script, good pacing and excellent cast, this made for cable movie is quite good and entertaining.  A bunch of bad guys led by supreme baddie Eric Roberts and Peter Stormare find themselves in the town of Refuge, a quaint little town where the sheriff doesn't wear a gun and there's no cussing on the streets.  We soon find out there's more to Refuge than meets the eye and the movie climaxes with a big gun fight to rival the best.  Along with Roberts and Stormare, the cast is perfect:  Sam Shepard, the laconic sheriff; Randy Quaid, the kindly doc; singer John David Souther as the general storekeeper; Donnie Wahlberg as the somewhat feisty deputy; Amelia Heinle as the lovely Rose; and Brad Rowe as the naive member of the bad guys.  It's quite different and should appeal to both fans of westerns and ghost stories.
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: This was quite clearly a low budget film, that probably went straight to DVD because the studio wasn't huge.  That being said, they did a good job as a whole, with the period dress being convincing, people actually getting dirty, and going into some deeper issues than are generally covered in "Westerns".  The acting was decent, nothing amazing.  The concept was interesting, and pretty well done.  Not a whole lot of actual "gun-fighting", per se, but there was a bit.  Definitely worth watching, though I certainly wouldn't nominate it for any awards.
summary: good quality for the low budget

reviewText: When a few outlaws (led by Eric Roberts and Peter Stormare) enter upon a mysterious town, they get more than they bargained for in Purgatory: an intriguing allegory made for cable channel TNT.  All the legendary names of the Wild West, including Billy the Kid (Donnie Wahlberg), Wild Bill (Sam Shepard), and Doc Holiday (Randy Quaid); all of whom attempting to redeem their souls for the acts committed while they were alive.  Naturally, a conflict ensues, with the townsfolk reluctantly resorting to the violent means they have been trying to erase.  Purgatory packs enough action for western enthusiasts, even though it may come off as too preachy for some, and while it wears thin towards the end, it still manages to be solid entertainment with an intriguing idea.  If you dig westerns with a twist on redemption, check out Purgatory.
Title: Purgatory VHS

Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: I think this will come to be considered the last mature, truly great western of the century of westerns. I've heard this described both as a "metaphysical" western and as a morality play. Maybe so, the really great westerns have always been about the eternal sruggle between good and evil, right and wrong. This film just carries it to a higher plane.I like the concept of men who walked the razor edge between Good and Bad being allowed one more chance to toe the line. There's alot about the character of Bill Hickok, Jesse James, Doc Holliday, and Billy the Kid that is not black and white- there's alot of gray.But, what happens when outside evil comes to Purgatory and you've sworn off violence forever? It must take a special kind of soul to disobey the Creator, even if it for a good cause, even when you know it means being cast into Hell....I still get chills from that closing line, "The Creator may be hard, but He ain't blind."By the way, once he gets going, Quaid steals the show as Doc Holliday.
summary: The last truly great western of the 20th century
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: A surprisingly engrossing allegory, stylish and original. And certainly entertaining! Anyone taking this film too literally, in one way or another, could be annoyed by it. It's like a fairy tale not for children. And the moral of the story is; everything is relative to motivation, and a pure and unselfish motive justifies all conduct. Moral relativism is something many people love or hate, depending on the circumstances, but few can ignore. Speaking for myself only, there is nothing absolute about this concept. A super job of direction and pace. Unique and memorable. A film most will appreciate at some level I think.

reviewText: Kudos to every aspect of this western!!!  Excellent script, directing, and acting.  fine performances from Sam Shepherd, Randy Quaid, Eric Roberts, and on down the line.Purgatory is where gunslingers,bank robbers, harlots,  and other shady characters go after they die to earn their way into god's good graces.  How?  By becoming residents of a town called Refuge.  By becoming pacifists.  By resisting the things that their former lives were built around.  In short, by being good.  This is where you find Wild Bill (Sam Shepherd), Doc Holiday (Randy Quaid), Billy the Kid (Donnie Wahlberg) and many others.  This is also where you find Blackjack Britton (Eric Roberts) and his gang.  Except they are very much alive.  After a bloody bank robbery, they happen upon Refuge as they flee a posse formed to apprehend them.  They'd have been better off caught.At first thought they believe they have found the perfect hideout.  but as time goes on they begin to expect other forces than simple fate are at work here.  Of course this all culminates in a showdown.  Nice twist and sub-plots are developed, with a stellar cast.  Excellent watch and addition to your western collection that you will watch time and again!!!

reviewText: I think the best description I could give you in a nutshell is: The Wild Bunch Meet the Twilight Zone!  What happens is; a bunch of really nasty bad guys somehow go "One Step Beyond" and wind up in a very lovely town called Refuge.  What's so strange is that nobody seems to be wearing any firearms, and they only get up tight if you curse.  The baddies can't figure out just what this place is all about, but the nephew of one of the baddies isn't really bad and, because he's into dime novels, he recognizes who some of the residents really are.  I refuse to be a spoiler, so if you want to know how it all turns out, buy the DVD and see for yourself.  I remembered it from when it appeared on TV many moons ago, and I still like it.  I'm sure, if you do buy it, you'll also fall in love with it.  It's really a great movie.

reviewText: 1999. Made for TV.  Excellent in every way.  Story.  Actors.  Everything.  It is not the hero that makes this film work, it's the villain.  Eric Roberts is perfect as the amoral outlaw.  Sam Shepard and the rest of the cast are wonderful, too.  J.D. Souther plays Jesse James, by the way.  Good job, too.  He is a great songwriter.  The Eagles.  Ronstadt.  Taylor.  Anyway, I don't know what it is about this movie.  I can watch it again and again and it always gives me a good feeling.  Maybe it's the idea that it really is a just world where the good are ultimately rewarded and the evil punished.  I'm not sure, but I am sure that you will feel the same way.  For 5 bucks, it's worth finding out, isn't it?  When was the last time a film made you feel that there is a plan for your life and you can feel pretty good about it?

reviewText: I must concur with the other reviewers in that I am not by habit a fan of Westerns (I like Tombstone, but that is about it - so obviously I like Western's with a darker vein running through them), but I absolutely loved this movie.  DARK is precisely what this film is!  I was coaxed into watching it, and at first I thought I was in for the usual wild west mayhem.  Then the outlaws arrive in the town of Refuge.  Okay, the people seem a bit odd, it now begins to draw me in...and then the church bells begin to chime.  I have never forgotten those bells.  They creeped me out something fierce.  It was at this point that I had gone silent in my viewership - which for me, is proof that the story completely has my attention.  If I am watching it Mystery Science Theatre style, then you know I am bored.  But this film had me running silent for its duration.  This was a really wonderful film.  The acting was good, the special effects were good, and the disturbing factor was right through the roof.  It's not jumping out of your seat horror or anything, if you are expecting that, then you will be disappointed, but if you find that horror is more in things that make you think about your own fate, then this movie will leave you speechless.  This is one of those films that you will talk about after it is over.  This is a film about choices, redemption and yes, damnation - and regardless of faith or religion, it touches on concepts that are relevant to everyone.  I would highly recommend this film to anyone who enjoys a good character study, philosophy, and oh yeah, westerns!
summary: If you combined Stephen King and Louis L'amour

reviewText: .Since the beginning of time, humans have been concern with the afterlife.  What happens when we die?  If we are judged, what are the standards?  Purgatory gives us some answers.The story is set in the American "wild west."  A gang of "outlaws" wanders into a remote town called Refuge, where it is so peaceful that the sheriff and his deputy do not carry firearms.  The sheriff invites them to stay awhile and says they are welcome to free drinks and rooms.  The only request is that they do not swear.Among the peaceful people of Refuge are dead western legends Wild Bill Hickok (Sam Shepard), Doc Holliday (Randy Quaid),. Jesse James (J.D. Souther), and Billy the Kid (Donnie Wahlberg). Seems that everyone in Refuge was violent in their past but given a chance to redeem their pasts in Purgatory.The outlaw gang enjoys the free entertainment but soon grows bored and decides they want more.  They are given some hints as to the nature of the town, like when one of them throws a knife at the sheriff in an attempt to kill him, but is struck by lightening  just as he is launching the throw.  Despite the hints the gang decides to assault the town and take whatever entertainment and loot they can.The confrontation between the violent outlaws and peaceful citizens of Refuge is impressive.  The incidents after the battle teach the audience  about end of life activities and standards for avoiding Hell and obtaining Heaven.I enjoyed Purgatory.  It does teach morals but in a way that is palatable.
Title: Purgatory VHS

reviewText: It's hard for me to say anything that hasn't already been said about this movie, but I will say this:I watched  this movie not knowing that this was a TNT original movie. When I finished watching it one of my friends told me it was made for TV. I almost couldn't beleive him because I have never seen a movie that was made for TV that was as good as this was.  And to top it off I'm not even that fond of western movies. The only western movie I've ever really liked was Tombstone. So this has got to be a great movie.The story is very interesting and the final showdown at the end is awesome. I don't want to say anything else because I don't want to ruin it for anyone.
summary: This movie should've been in theaters!

reviewText: At first this appears to be a normal gritty Western film.  Bad guy gang robs a bank, big shoot out, chased by a posse.But then things turn different. They ride into the little town of Refuge, where the Sheriff doesn't carry a gun, and where everyone goes to church. One of the gang, the youngest and most innocent, notes that the Sheriff (and others) look strangely familiar.Combining elements of a western, with touches of the supernatural, a nice little romance, and a cracking great gunfight scene.
